instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No signs of liquid damage on this board or machine at all. Doesn't appear to have been cleaned previously.
Sometimes I get a short (5 seconds or so) fanspin out of the board and the CPU heats up but it's sporadic and nothing sustained.


Green light so one wire is working
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - multimeter (fluke) goes crazy get lightning bolt icon indicates 3.4v-34.4v not seen this before
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> switching between 3.25 and 3.41v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> unstable 0 to 3.41 bouncing about every half a second.
audible faint ticking corresponding with the power fluctuation near the <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> area (I think) unhooked the fan and it still faintly clicks.

<RESISTOR>R8000</RESISTOR>,8011,8050,8020 not shorted to ground
PP3V S5, S4RS3, S3, S0 not shorted to ground
PP5V S5, S3, S0 not shorted to ground

Tried reflowing (or rehotting as Louis was joking the other day) the SMC, no change.
I'm a bit stuck at this point. Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: PPBUS voltage? Seeing any activity on L7520 or L7560?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> varies a little between 8.58 and 8.65 on <RESISTOR>R7006</RESISTOR>, doing the same fluctuating on both sides of F7140
L7520 shows a the - sign flashing on and off and a small number of volts like .005v fluctuating
L7560 is cycling from 0 to 3.3 or so volts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 19667"]Voltage on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>??[/QUOTE]

A steady 3.42 V on L7095.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Inspect corrosion in <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> area and pin8 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>. If that is all good, this board is gonna suck. Could really be anything.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yeah no corrosion anywhere unfortunately. Looking at the schematic could a faulty <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> cause improper signaling to <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> (which looks like it creates <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>) and that cause the fluctuations on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>? Is there anyway to meter <SIGNAL>CHGR_LGATE</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CHGR_UGATE</SIGNAL> to know if the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> is working properly to communicate to <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> how long to pulse to make <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

Using a different charger (both are OEM) I get about an 11 second fan spin, then off and then on for a split second and then off again permanently.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Is the 10 seconds fan spin then off always happening or is it random at times?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
it's random unfortunately. Sometimes it does it right away when the charger is connected and sometimes it doesn't :/

It wasn't doing it and I pressed down on the <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> area and it started doing it. No idea if that means anything for real or if it's a red herring.

10 sec on, one off, small blip... then about 30 seconds off and repeat.

heatsink is getting hot during this. I'll take a small video of a few cycles of it and post it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yeah, this is not a board you really want to mess with. I bet this machine was dropped. Probably a ripped trace/pad somewhere.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
donor board it is... :(

It did not die in vain. It gave it's <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> so that another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> might live again. 
First board I've fixed too.
